name: Startup Business Cockpit
text: The Startup Business Cockpit is a business support tool designed to assist in the creation and management of a startup business. It is built on Svelte and AWS.
The frontend is built with Svelte, Flowbite and D3, and the backend uses several Amazon Web Services such as Cognito and DynamoDB.
The application's authentication and authorisation allows different levels of permissions between members of the same company.
Every API is protected by an authorisation check and every new entry to the database is first checked with Zod to ensure the integrity of the database items.
Both the frontend and the backend were primarily built by me, from idea to product, with occasional help.

name: Tribes
text: My final project at SPICED Academy, TRIBES, is a prehistoric themed browser game coded in HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, node.js, react.js, Redux, socket.io and Amazon Web Services.
The main menu is also the game lobby. Here you can either create a new character (new game) or continue with an old one. All your progress is stored in the database.
The prologue is a sequence of story text and questions, and a new character is created based on these questions. The user is then asked to choose a name and a portrait.
Once the character has been created, the player will be taken to the tutorial, where the various mechanics of the game will be explained.
The chat component has a global chat, where any user can write to anyone, or personal chats between two users who are 'friends'.
In the lobby, you can add a user picture and a bio to your profile. The username and email can also be changed, provided no other user is using them.

name: imageBoard
text: The 'image board' project I created during the SPICED Full Stack Bootcamp, heavily inspired by the minimalist design of unsplash.com, uses Vue.js, AWS and PostgreSQL.
To upload your own image, you must first create an account. During this step, you will be given the option to add a profile picture, in which case a preview will be shown to the user.
In the image upload window, the user selects the file and a preview is generated. The user then needs to add a title and description to the image. Optionally, the user can add some tags to the image.
When the user moves the cursor over an image, its title is displayed.

When the user clicks on an image, a new window opens containing the same image in a higher resolution. The window will also contain the details of the image along with the comments associated with it.
